Note that the general difference in length of vowels is important  because otherwise words could get mixed up and it could end up in great confusion.

Note that the 'doubling' of consonants is also very important not to get confused. A doubled consonant is pronounced in both syllables whereas a single consonant is  pronounced in one syllable.

Also note the following complicated pronunciations.

; dh : Can be viewed as flapped
depending on the speaker - either way you'll get it right. Set your mouth to pronounce as normal

, but then curl your tongue  right up so that the bottom touches the top part of your mouth. As you try you'll fell your tongue flapping forward.
; x : It's more of an emphantic version of

. Take the exhaling sound you make when you've just burnt your mouth after taking a sip of boiling hot soup, push it right back into the very back of your mouth, making sure your tongue also goes back and that should be a good approximation.
; c : If you follow the same pronunciation rules for
, with the tongue and back of the mouth all pressed up against the back of the throat then simply change the hiss of the
to a sound using your vocal cords. If you're then sounding if you being choked then that's it. Hint: Think of

as a vowel modifier and  if listening to a natie speaker, note how it changes thevowel in its vicinity 'pharyngealized' the vowel, sending half the sound up the nose.
; q : It's pronounced like a
but right back in the mouth at the throat end, in the same area as
. Imagine you've got a marble in the back of the throat and that you're bouncing it using only the glottis and make a

sound at the same time.
; kh : It's the rasping
. It's also pronounced like the Spanish

ota.
; ' : It's what's called the glottal stop. You simply close the glottis at the very back of the mouth/top of throat, and then release the built-up air. The result is a light

sound with a very slight grunt just before it. Althought it's not written, it occurs in the conversational speech of nearly all English speakers, being most noticeable in the pronunciation of words like bottle as 'bo'el' by many Londoners
